channel.title: Client Version
channel.description: I was just wondering, Say a client had a frame title of "ServerName", but no Client version number next to it without having the src would it be possible to find out the client version? and how?

item.title: Client Version
item.dc:creator: @freaky5000 freaky5000
item.description:
@freaky5000 wrote:

Yeah i’ve sorted it, i got whole of a jadder off a friend, extracted the .jar got the class files, got the version number. Cheers for your help.

Read full topic

item.title: Client Version
item.dc:creator: @BuyMyJunk BuyMyJunk
item.description:
@BuyMyJunk wrote:

freaky5000:

I was just wondering, Say a client had a frame title of “ServerName”, but no Client version number next to it without having the src would it be possible to find out the client version? and how?

you mean like reading tthe class version.class file?
get your hands on a a java decompiler, and use it to open the .class file and just get the number that way

Read full topic

item.title: Client Version
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I would use reflection or something similar…

Here is an example, using my previously released MoonSpell server (I cannot find the RSCDaemon client source)…

try { Integer version = (Integer)Class.forName("com.sksdbase.moonspell.Version").getDeclaredField("VERSION_CLIENT").get(null); } catch(Exception e) { System.out.println("Error: This Class or Field does not exist!"); }

Perhaps an even better version would be the following:

try { int version = Class.forName("com.sksdbase.moonspell.Version").getDeclaredField("VERSION_CLIENT").getInt(null); } catch(Exception e) { System.out.println("Error: This Class or Field does not exist!"); }

Read full topic
